docs.text: libby parsons ( ashley judd ) has the perfect little life -- a rich husband , a cute son , and a house on the ocean -- but when her husband nick ( bruce greenwood ) takes her sailing , she awakes to find him gone and her hands covered with blood .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: just as she makes it to the deck and picks up the bloody knife lying there , the coast guard arrives in response to a distress call her vanished husband sent .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: she's convicted of his murder , of course , and leaves her son matty ( benjamin weir ) with her best friend ( annabeth gish ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: time passes , and the friend disappears with matty .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: during their last phone conversation libby hears matty yell " daddy ! "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: and realizes that her husband is still alive .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: libby serves six years , growing harder and driven by the desire to kill nick ( based on the theory that because of the " double jeopardy " amendment she can off him with impunity ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: when she gets parole , she's sent to a halfway house run by travis lehman ( tommy lee jones ) , a former law professor who ruined his life with a drunk driving accident .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: after a little breaking and entering and some destruction of property , libby jumps parole and lams it across the country looking for nick and matty .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: travis pursues , naturally .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " double jeopardy " is a watered-down version of " the fugitive , " with jones sleep-walking through his well-worn pursuer persona .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: although libby never leaps from a bus that collides with a train , she manages to get into a few nail-biters -- chased down the beach by a jeep , chained to a car that plunges into the ocean , sealed in a coffin -- that add some much needed thrills to an anemic , slow-moving script .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: character development is thin .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: travis' intriguing backstory is mentioned a couple times but has no effect on the story .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: ( i think they only made him a former law professor so that he could verify the double-jeopardy theory when libby gets the drop on nick .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's a long way to go for one line ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there's considerable sexual tension between travis and libby ( hey , there's something " the fugitive " didn't have ! ) , but it never goes anywhere .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: libby is a tv-movie everywoman , but judd's intense performance draws us in and makes us forget that her character has no distinguishing characteristics .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this is judd's most prominent role to date , and she proves that she can light up the screen .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: let's hope hollywood gives her more to work with next time around .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the quality of director bruce beresford's movies seems to depend on luck .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: when he has a good script and a strong cast , he turns out oscar-caliber work like " 'breaker' morant , " " driving miss daisy , " and " tender mercies . "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: when he doesn't .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: we get " double jeopardy . "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: screenwriters david weisberg and douglas cook previously collaborated on " the rock , " a script which probably benefited from the numerous uncredited rewrites .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: bottom line : ashley judd tries hard but can't save this predictable bore .
docs.label: negative
